H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15: A novel reusable organic–inorganic hybrid material as potent Lewis acid catalyst for one-pot solvent-free synthesis of 3,4-dihydropyrimidinones Reza Tayebee a ⁎ Mostafa M. Amini b Malihe Ghadamgahi a Mahsa Armaghan b a Department of Chemistry, School of Sciences, Hakim Sabzevari University, Sabzevar 96179-76487, Iran b Department of Chemistry, Shahid Beheshti University, G.C., Tehran, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 571 4410300; fax: +98 571 4410300. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Modification of SBA-15 with piperazine to avoid leaching of the heteropolyacid. ► An environmentally friendly protocol to afford dihydropyrimidinones. ► SBA/Pip/H5PW10V2O40 as a new organic–inorganic hybrid material. ► Piperazine behaved as the best among various organic linkers. A simple and environmentally friendly one-pot three components methodology has been commented for the Biginelli condensation of different substituted aldehydes with ethyl acetoacetate and urea to afford the corresponding 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2-(1H)-ones under solvent-free conditions. H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 was used as a non-toxic, inexpensive, and easily available organic–inorganic hybrid material as the catalyst. Utilization of easy reaction condition and simple work-up makes this methodology as an interesting option for the economic synthesis of dihydropyrimidinones. Keywords 3,4-Dihydropyrimidin-2-(1H)-ones Solvent free Reusable Heterogeneous Catalytic 1 Introduction Dihydropyrimidinones (DHPMs) or Biginelli compounds are important medicinal synthones which exhibit a wide range of biological activities such as antiviral, anti-tumour, antibacterial and anti-inflammatory actions [1–3]. Many of the dihydropyrimidinone derivatives are pharmacologically important as potent calcium channel blockers, antihypertensive agents, antagonists, and neuropeptide antagonists [4–9]. Moreover, several marine alkaloids involving the DHPM core unit, such as batzelladine alkaloids, have exhibited interesting biological properties. A wide range of protocols have been introduced for the synthesis of 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-ones using ceric ammonium nitrate [10], Lewis acids such as BF3·Et2O and Sr(NO3)2 [11,12], and heteropolyacids [13] as catalysts. However, in spite of their potential utility, most of these protocols involve expensive reagents, strongly acidic conditions, long reaction times, high temperatures, stoichiometric amounts of catalysts, and unsatisfactory yields. Therefore, the discovery of new and inexpensive catalysts for the preparation of 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-ones under mild conditions is of prime importance. In recent years, several studies have been carried out on the modification of silica supports with organic linkers to inhibit leaching of the active heteropolyacids from the solid support. The functional groups may enhance the interactions of heteropolyacids with the supporting material via hydrogen bonding, electrostatic interactions, and chemical bonding and allow higher and more stable loading. Herein, we report for the first time the heterogeneous solvent-free Biginelli reaction of aldehydes, urea, and ethyl acetoacetate using H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 as a solid acid catalyst (Scheme 1 ). Effect of some organic linkers on the efficacy of the heterogeneous catalyst is also studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods The used chemicals were purchased from Aldrich chemical company and Merck and used as received. All products were characterized by comparison of their spectral and physical data with those reported in the literature [14]. Progress of the reactions was monitored by TLC. Infrared spectra were recorded on 8700 Shimadzu Fourier Transform spectrophotometer using KBr windows. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AVANCE 300-MHz instrument using TMS as an internal reference. Data for 1H NMR are reported as follows: chemical shift (δ) and multiplicity (s: singlet, d: doublet, t: triplet, q: quartet, m: multiplet, qt: quintuple, dq: doublet of quartets, br: broad). The heteropolyacid catalyst was prepared and characterized according to the literature procedures [15]. X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained on a STOE diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Thermal analysis (TG–DTA) was carried on a Bahr STA-503 instrument under air atmosphere with heating rate of 10°C/min. Electron microscopy was performed on a Phillips XL-30 scanning electron microscope (SEM). 2.2 General procedures for the preparation of 3,4-dihdropyrimidin-2(1H)-ones A solution of ethyl acetoacetate (2mmol), aldehyde (2mmol) and urea (2.5mmol) was heated to 100°C under solvent-free condition in the presence of H5PW10V2O40 supported on piperazine modified SBA-15 (0.6g of catalyst was involved 2mol% of H5PW10V2O40). Completion of the reaction was monitored by TLC. After completion, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, dissolved in methanol and filtered to separate the catalyst. Methanol was evaporated and the crude product was poured into crushed ice with thorough stirring for 5min. The solid product was filtered and further purified by re-crystallization from n-hexane/ethyl acetate (3:1), to afford pure 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-ones. 2.3 Spectral data of some selected compounds 2.3.1 Ethyl-6-methyl-2-oxo-4-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydropyrimidine-5-carboxylate IR (KBr, cm−1): 3238, 3113, 2980, 1724, 1649, 1465, 1290. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6), δ (ppm): 1.09 (t, 3H, CH3), 2.24 (s, 3H, CH3), 3.99 (q, 2H, CH2), 5.13 (d, 1H, H-4), 7.21–7.34 (m, 5H, Harom), 7.73 (s, 1H, NH), 9.19 (s, 1H, NH). 13C NMR (DMSO-d6), δ (ppm): 14.5, 18.2, 54.5, 59.7, 99.8, 126.7, 127.7, 128.8, 145.3, 148.8, 152.8, 165.8. 2.3.2 Ethyl-6-methyl-4-(2-chlorophenyl)-2-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydropyrimidine-5-carboxylate IR (KBr, cm−1): 3354, 3236, 3111, 2978, 1693, 1641, 1226, 1095. 1H NMR (DMSO-d6), δ (ppm): 0.99 (t, 3H, CH3), 2.30 (s, 3H, CH3), 3.90 (q, 2H, CH2), 5.63 (d, 1H, H-4), 7.25–7.41 (m, 4H, Harom), 7.71 (s, 1H, NH), 9.27 (s, 1H, NH). 13C NMR (DMSO-d6), δ (ppm): 14.4, 18.1, 51.9, 59.5, 98.3, 128.2, 129.2, 129.5, 129.8, 132.1, 142.2, 149.8, 151.8, 165.4. 2.3.3 Ethyl-6-methyl-4-(4-nitrophenyl)-2-oxo-1, 2, 3,4-tetrahydropyrimidine-5-carboxylate IR (KBr, cm−1): 3215, 1731, 1707, 1641; 1H NMR (DMSO-d6), δ (ppm): 1.07 (3H, t, 3J 6.8Hz, CH3), 2.26 (3H, s, CH3), 3.97 (2H, q, 3J 5.4Hz, OCH2), 5.27 (1H, s, CH), 7.50 (2H, d, 3J 7.3Hz, Harom), 7.87 (1H, s, NH), 8.20 (2H, d, 3J 7.2Hz, Harom), 9.33 (1H, s, NH). 13C NMR (DMSO-d6), δ (ppm): 14.5, 18.3, 54.2, 59.8, 98.7, 124.2, 128.1, 147.2, 149.8, 152.2, 152.5, 165.5. 2.3.4 Ethyl-6-methyl-4-(4-methylphenyl)-2-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydropyrimidine-5-carboxylate IR (KBr, cm−1): 3326, 3152, 1691, 1562, 1232, 1051, 783; 1H NMR (DMSO-d6): δ (ppm): 1.10 (t, J =7.5Hz, 3H, OCH2CH3), 2.28 (s, 3H, C6H5-CH3), 3.96 (q, J =7.5Hz, 2H, OCH2CH3), 5.10 (s, 1H, CH), 7.15 (s, 4H, Harom), 7.70 (br s, 1H, NH), 9.19 (br s, 1H, NH). 13C NMR (DMSO-d6), δ (ppm): 165.3, 152.2, 148.1, 141.9, 136.3, 128.8, 126.1, 99.5, 59.1, 53.7, 20.6, 17.7, 14.1. 2.3.5 Ethyl-6-methyl-4-(3-nitrophenyl)-2-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydropyrimidine-5-carboxylate IR (KBr, cm−1): 3300, 3120, 1710, 1690, 1630; Pluronic P123 was used as template, and the silica source was TEOS, which was added drop wise to an acidic P123 aqueous solution and then stirred at 40°C for 24h at 600rpm. The reaction mixture was acidified by adding HCl aqueous solution. The molar ratio of the reaction mixture was 1 TEOS:0.0168 P123:5.8 HCl:155 H2O. The powder was recovered by filtration, dried overnight, and further calcined at 600°C for 6h [17]. 2.5 Immobilization of piperazine onto SBA-15 0.7g of activated SBA-15 mesoporous silica was suspended in 5ml of dry toluene. To this suspension, a mixture of 0.35ml 3-(trimethoxysilyl)propylchloride in 0.6ml of toluene was added drop wise. The resulting mixture was mechanically stirred under reflux for 24h. Then, the mixture was filtered off and the solid washed with toluene and ethanol, and finally, the solid product was transferred to a Soxhlet extractor to eliminate the excess of reagents with ethanol. The resulted precursor with SiCl functional group on the surface was dried in the vacuum for 8h at 100°C. The reaction scheme is illustrated in Scheme 2 . In the next step, this modified mesoporous silica was suspended in 10.0ml of toluene and suspension was maintained under reflux with mechanical stirring. Then 0.106mol of piperazin was added and allowed to stand for another 24h. After cooling, the solid SiPip was filtered, washed successively with toluene, de-ionized water, ethanol, and acetone. Then, the resulting precipitate was transferred to a Soxhlet extractor to eliminate the excess of reagents, by treating the solid with ethanol. Finally, the resulting solid was dried in the vacuum for 12h at room temperature [18]. 2.6 Immobilization of H5PW10V2O40 on Pip-SBA-15 A 50ml sample of methanol solution containing 0.3g of H5PW10V2O40 was added to 0.7g of freshly activated Pip-SBA-15 and refluxed for 3h. It was then filtered, soxhleted with methanol for 12h, and dried at 100°C under vacuum. The resulting product is designated as H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 [19]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of the hybrid material 3.1.1 FT-IR spectroscopy FT-IR analysis is applied to shed light on the structure of hybrid material. FT-IR spectra of free H5PW10V2O40 (A), pip-SBA-15 (B), and HPA impregnated pip-SBA-15 mesoporous support, H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 (C) are studied for structural characterization purposes (Fig. 1 ). The Keggin type heteropolyacid showed four characteristic peaks in the range of 750–1100cm−1 [20]. Earlier reports assigned these peaks that appeared at about 778–785 and 850–890cm−1 to WOW. The peaks around 950–998 and 1070–1090cm−1 are associated with MO and PO bonds, respectively, and explicitly indicate the neat structure of Keggin-type heteropolyacid. In the FT-IR spectrum of H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 these four peaks slightly overlapped with Pip-SBA-15, however, spectrum (C) confirmed that loading of heteropolyacid was occurred over Pip-SBA-15 and H5PW10V2O40 was successfully immobilized on the pores of SBA-15 support via strong chemical interaction between the two components. 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction study The low-angle X-ray diffraction patterns of SBA-15, Pip-SBA-15, and HPA/Pip-SBA-15 are depicted in Fig. 2 . The patterns illustrated an intense peak at 2θ about 1.7° which assigned to (100) reflection and indicating a significant degree of long-range ordering in the structure and a well-formed hexagonal lattice. The diffraction patterns indicated that the primary structure of SBA-15 is maintained after modification with piperazine and anchoring with HPA. The XRD pattern of HPA/Pip-SBA-15 in particular shows the effect of the HPA loading on the XRD pattern of SBA-15. HPA loading induced a striking effect on the width and intensity of the main reflection at high d 100 spacing (2θ =1.7°) and this line becomes broader and weaker with a marginal shift towards lower 2θ values. This suggested that the long-range order of SBA-15 is decreased noticeably by the presence of HPA. The decrease in the intensity of reflections, which is well-known in immobilization of various catalysts on mesoporous silicas, is attributed to the occupation of mesopore channels [21]. Bulk HPA crystal phase does not appear in the HPA supported Pip-SBA-15 material, indicating that HPA is finely dispersed on the Pip-SBA-15 support. 3.1.3 SEM studies The SEM micrographs of SBA-15, Pip-SBA-15 and HPA/Pip-SBA-15 are shown in Fig. 3a–c, respectively. SEM micrographs show robe-like morphology, which is consistent with known SBA-15 structure [22,23]. SEM images also provide evidence for the structural integrity of SBA-15 and Pip-SBA-15. Apparently, functionalization with piperazine and anchoring had no a significant effect on the structure of pure SBA-15. However, mono-layer coverage of Pip-SBA-15 surface by HPA did change morphology, which clearly indicates HPA immobilized and well dispersed on the surface of Pip-SBA-15. 3.1.4 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA–DTA) of Pip-SBA-15 Fig. 4 represents the thermogravimetric analysis profile of Pip-SBA-15. The first mass loss step below 100°C which accompanied with an endothermic peak in DSC curve is due to the removal of physically adsorbed water, and the second mass loss in the temperature range of 100–200°C is associated with the loss of chemically bonded water or surface silanol condensation. The mass loss in the temperature range of 200–600°C which accompanied with an exothermic peak in DSC curve is due to the combustion of piperazine and propyl chain. The mass loss due to organic groups in the temperature range between 200 and 600°C gave a piperazine concentration of 1.0mmol/g in the final mesoporous solid. 3.2 Studying effect of catalyst amount on the condensation reaction The catalytic reactions were carried out by the addition of H5PW10V2O40 supported on piperazine modified SBA-15, H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15, to a mixture of benzaldehyde, ethylacetoacetate and urea with thorough stirring in the absence of solvent under conventional heating to 100°C to prepare 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-one derivatives in good to excellent yields. This three component Biginelli condensation in the presence of H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15, which included low catalyst concentration (2mol%) of heteropolyacid, selectively led to the corresponding 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-one in 90% yield at 100°C under solvent-free condition after 20min. The catalytic efficiency of H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 heterogeneous catalytic system was studied for the synthesis of 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-ones with various catalyst amounts (Table 1 ). At first, a model reaction was carried in the absence of catalyst. The reaction of benzaldehyde, ethyl acetoacetate and urea did not afford an appreciable amount of the desired 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-one in the absence of catalyst after the extended time of 9h; whereas, 0.15g of catalyst involving 0.5mol% polyoxometalate, afforded 74% of conversion after 2.9h. This finding revealed that the heterogeneous catalyst exhibited high catalytic activity in the desired transformation. Table 1, show enhancing the amount of catalyst, initially, led to high yield at short reaction time and 0.6g of catalyst was enough to endorse the reaction. Higher amount, 0.75g, resulted in diminishing yield to 81% at the longer time (1h). This behavior would be explained considering the fact that increasing in the number of active sites with enhancing catalyst amount, results decreasing concentration of reactants at the active sites, which leads to decline in yield%. Furthermore, polarity, pH, and identity of the reaction mixture may be other contributing factors. 3.3 Effect of reaction temperature on the condensation reaction Effect of reaction temperature on the Biginelli reaction of aldehydes, urea, and ethyl acetoacetate using H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 was studied. As is expected, the reaction time was influenced by temperature. Results summarized in Fig. 5 show that the efficacy of the reaction was clearly decreased below 90°C; whereas, increasing the reaction temperature from 90 to 120°C had a little effect on the yield%. Therefore, considering technical points of view, the temperature 100°C was selected for all reactions. 3.4 Synthesis of different 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-ones After optimizing the reaction condition, generality of the method was evaluated by the reaction of different substituted aromatic aldehydes with electron withdrawing and electron releasing substituents on the phenyl ring in the presence of 0.6g H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 (Table 2 ). Aromatic aldehydes bearing either electron releasing and/or electron withdrawing groups afforded high yields of products with excellent selectivity. This procedure not only preserves the simplicity of Biginelli reaction but also affords good yields of 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-ones under heterogeneous condition. 3.5 Comparing superiority of H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 over some reported catalysts The superiority of the present protocol over some reported methods can be studied by comparing the obtained results with those reported previously (Table 3 ). The three component condensation of urea, acetoacetate, and 4-nitrobenzaldehyde to prepare ethyl-6-methyl-4-(4-nitrophenyl)-2-oxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydropyrimidine-5-carboxylate was selected as a model reaction and the comparison was in terms of mol% of catalysts, reaction time, and percentage yield. Although, some of the reported additives led to marginally higher conversions, however, they required longer reaction times and higher mol% of catalyst. The present methodology used low catalyst amount (2mol%) of a cheap and environmentally friendly heterogeneous catalyst under solvent-free condition and required relatively shorter reaction times. 3.6 Effect of different organic linkers on the catalytic efficiency of H5PW10V2O40 Obviously, solid supporting materials and organic modifiers have strong effects on the efficiency of H5PW10V2O40 to catalyze the condensation reaction. Therefore, some modified and un-modified beds were examined in the synthesis of 3,4-dihydropyrimidins (Table 4 ). SBA-15 mesoporous silica with well ordered hexagonal arrays of cylindrical channels, narrow pore size distributions, remarkable thermal stability, large uniform pore size (5–30nm), high surface area (600–1000 m2/g), thick silica walls (3.1–6.4nm) [35,36], and a large number of silanol groups at the surface of its channels [37], serves as an intriguing support for the purpose of this report. Recent activities on the modification of silica supports have been achieved to control leaching of the active metal center from the solid support, in one hand, and increasing the catalytic efficacy, on the other. Functional groups may enhance the interactions of HPA with the support material either by physical forces (i.e. hydrogen bonding and electrostatic interactions) or chemical bonding and allow higher and more stable loading [19,38,39]. Therefore, this strategy is an important extension, since it allows significant modification of physical and chemical properties. Furthermore, rational design and tailoring of hydrophobicity, adsorption characteristics, and reactivity are possible with the hybrid organic/inorganic materials. Different organic linkers involving TPI, N-[3(triethoxysilyl)propyl]isonicotinamide), and piperazine were used to modify SBA-15. Among these organic modifiers, piperazine-containing SBA-15 led to the best results to activate H5PW10V2O40 and provided 90% of conversion after 0.3h (entry 22). H5PW10V2O40/MCM-48 occupied the second position and gave 86% yield after 0.8h (entry 23). TPI, was the least effective modifier for SBA-15 and led to <70% yield after long time 2.2h. Moreover, kind of the supporting material affected the reaction efficiency. For example, piperazin modified SBA-15 led to 90% of conversion after 0.3h; whereas, its SiO2 counterpart provided 93% yield after 5.3h. Pyridine modified magnetite, H5PW10V2O40/TPI-Fe3O4, as a new important organic–inorganic hybrid material also showed moderate reactivity and led to 68% yield after 1.8h. 3.7 Studying reusability of H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 Reusability of catalyst is an important feature of each proposed protocol. Our findings revealed that H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 is a recoverable catalyst. The used catalyst was washed with acetone, dried at 110°C for 2h and ground to a fine powder. The regenerated catalyst was used for another Biginelli reaction of aldehyde, urea and ethyl acetoacetate. After completion of the reaction, catalyst was recovered and reused in another reaction. Comparison of infra-red spectra of H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 before and after reaction was compared in the synthesis of 3,4-dihydropyrimidines (Fig. 6 ). Appearance of peaks around 800–1100cm−1 clearly confirmed preservation of Keggin structure of the heteropolyacid. These findings confirmed that the heterogeneous catalyst was reusable. Further investigations are carried out to prove the reusability of H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15. The catalyst was found to be reusable for at least 7 cycles without considerable loss of activity (Fig. 7 ). The chemical binding of H5PW10V2O40 to the surface of the modified solid support is responsible for the high reusability of the target catalyst. 3.8 Proposed reaction pathway for the preparation of 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-one A reasonable mechanistic pathway for the three components condensation of urea, ethyl acetoacetate, and an aldehyde to prepare 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-one in the presence of H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 is proposed as described in Scheme 3 [40]. 4 Conclusions H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15, as an environmentally friendly catalyst, was prepared and used for the solvent free synthesis of various 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2(1H)-ones via Biginelli reaction of benzaldehyde, urea, and ethyl acetoacetate. Excellent yield of 3,4-dihydropyrimidinones obtained in short duration and application of a non-toxic, easy to separate and recyclable catalyst making this methodology economically and environmentally acceptable. coredata.dc:description: A simple and environmentally friendly one-pot three components methodology has been commented for the Biginelli condensation of different substituted aldehydes with ethyl acetoacetate and urea to afford the corresponding 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2-(1H)-ones under solvent-free conditions. H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15 was used as a non-toxic, inexpensive, and easily available organic–inorganic hybrid material as the catalyst. Utilization of easy reaction condition and simple work-up makes this methodology as an interesting option for the economic synthesis of dihydropyrimidinones.
coredata.dc:title: H5PW10V2O40/Pip-SBA-15: A novel reusable organic–inorganic hybrid material as potent Lewis acid catalyst for one-pot solvent-free synthesis of 3,4-dihydropyrimidinones
